I remember some years ago when I saw my GP, there was an intern in the practice. That intern was a trainee GP. They would sit there and help with going through the process and going through the initial assessment. We saw a spike in people wanting to become general practitioners. But that has now gone, and WIPs and PIPs have also fallen by the wayside. Now we see less people wanting to be a GP, which is a fantastic career. I would encourage people to take up that program.
Education

Ms FERNANDO (Holt) (19:45): One of the most important things in life is education. My mother always used to tell my brother and me that education is priceless and will serve you for the rest of your life. I couldn't agree more with mum, and I always took her message to heart. Education is also a core focus of the Labor Party and this government. We know that empowering everyday Australians with the priceless gift of education is what helps to break intergenerational poverty, increases employment prospects, increases Australian innovation, and maintains our status as an education nation. This is why I'm so proud of the Albanese Labor government's investment in fee-free TAFE and VET courses for all Australians across the country.

In my state of Victoria, there are more than 55,000 fee-free TAFE and VET places on offer in 2023. This comes after a crucial agreement between the federal and state Labor governments to address current skills shortages. This investment of more than $250 million will deliver a substantial boost to our skills and training sector. This investment will help support around 26,900 placements in the care sector over the next 12 months and address roughly 3,800 early childhood education and care places. It will also greatly assist my state in reaching its target of 64,700 new workers in the education, health and community service sectors by 2025. These investments alone are crucial to my constituents, as my electorate of Holt is one of the youngest in Australia. In particular, the demand for early childhood education and care is through the roof.

This agreement also directly increases the opportunities and participation of several priority groups including young people aged 17 to 24, those currently out of work or receiving some form of income support, unpaid carers, people with disability, some categories of visa holders, and women studying in non-traditional fields. There are many certificate III and IV courses available, such as the Certificate III in Commercial Cookery, which I completed back in the day. Look where it has led me! Another fantastic course I completed was a cert III in school based education support, which directly led me to volunteer at AMES Australia, an experience I will always cherish. Other great opportunities include courses in agriculture, community services, disability, mental health, youth work, cybersecurity, ageing support, allied health assistance and many more. As we know, this investment is targeted to provide tailored support and empowerment to various sectors of our community that require extra support to get them into the programs they desire. We are making this investment because this Labor government always puts people first and invests in them. We know it is the people who make this country great.
It is also important to realise that this investment does not happen in a vacuum. Everything is connected. These education paths will flow on to create positive effects on our economy.

Not only are those who obtain skills likely to find jobs with higher incomes and greater job security, thus helping to break up the gig economy, but it means there are more disposable incomes to spend in the wider economy, spending more in hospitality, in small businesses and in the community. When this investment is paired with the Albanese government's signature policies like the National Reconstruction Fund and the Housing Australia Future Fund, we start to see the wider picture. Education opportunities opened up by this investment directly complement other investments by providing skilled workers to kickstart our domestic manufacturing, again through the NRF, or by constructing more social housing every year through the housing fund. We are getting on with job for all Australians so families like yours and mine are not left behind.
HomeBuilder Program

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin) (19:50): The highly successful HomeBuilder program, a scheme which continues to support thousands of new homebuyers and builders, is at risk under this Labor government. Worried HomeBuilder applicants at risk of losing their grants continue to contact my office, seeking our support to lobby the government to have the deadline extended. Anguished parents contact me on behalf of their children who are at risk of missing out on this significant assistance through no fault of their own. Housing projects have now been put at risk, with the government refusing to grant a further extension. Hundreds of aspiring homeowners across the country, therefore, could lose grants of up to $25,000 just because of supply constraints and unanticipated delays in the construction of their homes. Other delays, including administrative delays at a state and local government level, are causing these problems. At a time when every dollar counts, first homebuyers committed to purchasing a home with the assistance of the HomeBuilder grant, through no fault of their own, are potentially under financial stress because the Labor government will not assist them.

The HomeBuilder program gave Australians confidence and support to build or rebuild a home during a period of great uncertainty, as well as protecting jobs and boosting economic activity in the residential construction industry. We used housing policy to address other important objectives. We put in place the HomeBuilder program when the term 'valley of death' was the grim assessment from the residential construction industry, with 500,000 jobs at risk at the beginning of the pandemic. The program, which at that time provided $25,000 in grants for those who built a new home, which was derided by the then Labor opposition, resulted in 137,000 HomeBuilder projects generating $120 billion in economic activity, so, far from seeing jobs lost in the residential construction industry, we saw an industrywide boom. This was the perfect marriage between economic stimulus and our ongoing objective to support and encourage more first homebuyers—and you don't hear the term 'first homebuyers' from this government. This showed beyond any doubt that a government focused on homeownership can get results.

With the 30 April deadline fast approaching for HomeBuilder applicants to provide their supporting documentation, including evidence of construction commencement, the opposition is calling on the Labor government to urgently provide an extension of time to all existing applicants to ensure that they do not miss out on receiving their grants due to circumstances that are beyond their control. I'll use the example from the former coalition government. On 17 April 2021, I as then minister provided an extension of time to HomeBuilder applicants, allowing them at that time an additional 12 months to commence construction from the date the building contract was signed, and we implore the government to do the same. It is a very simple administrative fix. During this cost-of-living crisis, and with the added pressure of housing supply shortages, participants in the HomeBuilder program should not have to face financial hardship or have their projects jeopardised because the Labor government refuses to make this minor administrative change.

Responding to 9News Gold Coast in March, the housing minister revealed she has no plans to extend the deadline. Sadly, on any measure, the drift from the Albanese government in this respect is a concern. With first home buyers dropping, rents rising, new home sales dropping and construction activity in the residential industry dropping, things are getting worse, not better. The last thing that we can have now is Australians who, in good faith, have met all the criteria of the HomeBuilder grants and undertaken their projects but through no fault of their own are experiencing delays—whether because of supply chain difficulties or administrative delays in getting homes approved at a state or local government level—missing out on grants that they would otherwise receive. It's very simple for the Labor government: with the stroke of a pen, extend the deadline and ensure that hundreds of young Australians don't miss out on the HomeBuilder grant that will set them up for their future.

subdebateinfo.title: South Australian Government, Spence Electorate: Manufacturing

p.span: South Australian Government
Spence Electorate: Manufacturing

Mr BURNELL (Spence) (19:55): The past week has been quite a victorious one if you're from my state of South Australia. These achievements occurred one year after Peter Malinauskas led South Australia Labor back into government after only four years in opposition. That means my predecessor, the former member for Spence, Nick Champion, has now been part of the Peter Malinauskas Labor government as the Minister for Planning, Minister for Trade and Investment and Minister for Housing and Urban Development for over a year now. Time really does fly. The government has a number of accomplishments stemming from the statistics alone. Roughly 48 per cent of its election commitments have been fulfilled in their first year in government.

This brings me back to some of my first speeches on policy and legislation in this place, applauding our government for enacting legislation that formed part of a policy taken to the election. A couple of the many hallmarks of good Labor governments, federal or state, are a meticulous eye for keeping to election commitments and enacting big reforms and big moves, affecting states and the nation for years or generations into the future. Another hallmark is one that we do here every single day: correcting the mistakes and mess of the previous government.

Conversely, good Labor governments have taken the mantles of policies enacted by previous governments where it has been in the national interest to do so. Also within the last week, we have seen one of these policies come to fruition. That is, of course, the recent announcement made under the AUKUS partnership—one with long-lasting and positive benefits to South Australia. When the Prime Minister met with the UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and US President Joe Biden last week, for many in South Australia it ushered in not just happiness but also a great sense of relief.

To provide some historical context, we must go back to 2013 and to the floor of this very chamber, where the Treasurer of the day, Joe Hockey, made his infamous remarks daring GM-Holden to close up shop and cease operations in Australia, at a time when they were seeking financial support from the government so they could remain afloat. And what happened next? Well, one of two things would appear to be true. The first scenario involves Joe Hockey believing GM-Holden to be making idle threats and merely bluffing. The second scenario involves a wilful indifference to the consequences of GM-Holden following through with the statements they made about ceasing operations in Australia without further government support. Whichever way you look at it, neither scenario paints Joe Hockey and senior members of the government at the time in a particularly good light. I don't know much of the character of the man in order to pass proper judgement. I don't even know if he's any good at poker. But for the measure of a man I look to a quote from famed psychiatrist Sigmund Freud: 'Who knows? Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.' You can simply say, at this point, the rest was history.

An iconic automotive manufacturer closing anywhere within Australia is a tragic set of circumstances, but this occurred in the very heart of my electorate of Spence, named Wakefield at the time. Thousands of jobs were lost both directly and indirectly. Manufacturing is the lifeblood of the northern suburbs of Adelaide. The northern suburbs had been built as a satellite city around a manufacturing industry—one that many felt had its death knell rung the moment Joe Hockey told GM-Holden to leave.

But up north we are a resilient and innovative bunch. In the very place where Holden cars drove off the factory floor, there is now a place where mushrooms are cultivated by the Epicurean Food Group. Without such innovative ideas, the old plant would remain empty and serve as a reminder of what once was to those driving past. The north has built a burgeoning and thriving defence industry alongside RAAF Edinburgh and DSTG. With the AUKUS build taking place in South Australia, we now have a better degree of certainty. But now the Prime Minister has renewed the Australian government's vows to South Australia—

The DEPUTY SPEA
KER ( Ms Vamvakinou ): Order! In accordance with the resolution agreed to earlier, the time for the adjournment debate has concluded.
BILLS
Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2022
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Ms TINK (North Sydney) (20:00): Indeed, the report said that the economic costs of this approach are increasingly apparent, laying bare the reality that decisions to avoid technology-neutral, economy-wide abatement mechanisms do not avoid the pricing of emissions, but rather only lead to a myriad of very high implicit or shadow emissions and shadow prices. The Productivity Commission rightly identifies this legislation to be the principal economy-wide mechanism for achieving national abatement targets. But for this to be the case, we must empower it so it can achieve its full potential. Communities and households across the country, include my community in North Sydney, are already doing the heavy lifting on reducing emissions, installing household solar, choosing green electricity providers, reducing energy consumption and increasing energy efficiencies, making the switch from gas to renewables and shifting from petrol to electric cars or to active and public transport. But the reality is our emissions reduction challenge cannot be met by individuals alone. Australia's largest industrial facilities have a crucial role to play in reducing emissions in line with our national ambition. Any shortfall created by large industry not pulling their weight will have to be picked up by others.

As it currently stands, the safeguard mechanism only covers 215 facilities, each of which emits about 100,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions every year. This adds up to 140 million tonnes, which is equivalent to 28 per cent of Australia's total emissions. Gas extraction and coal mines make up 56 per cent of the emissions covered by the safeguard mechanism, and four of the top five emitters are gas export plants operated by Woodside, Chevron, and Impex. Strengthening the safeguard mechanism will ultimately future-proof our economy, as it will strengthen the investment drivers that guide decarbonisation of industrial processes. This will strengthen Australia's competitiveness in a carbon constrained global economy. Our largest exporters know that global markets are moving to a low-carbon future, with more than 80 per cent of Australia's trade covered by other countries' net zero commitments. Staying competitive and on track for net zero by 2050 will be critical to avoid penalties from carbon border tariffs imposed by other nations and trading partners in the future.

With all of this said, I am advocating for three key changes to this piece of legislation. They are one, restrict the use of offsets and ensure their quality; two, prevent new or expanding fossil fuel project from accessing government funding to purchase abatement; and three, bring more polluters into the mechanism over time. Emails from and conversations with people across my community leave me in no doubt that the people of North Sydney believe this legislation must be more explicit in conveying a clear hierarchy for true and gross emission reduction or on-site abatement prior to allowing facilities and industries to simply purchase Australian carbon credit units, ACCUs, as a way of netting out their emissions. The absence of any limit on the purchase of ACCUs creates a significant risk that the reformed safeguard mechanism will allow continued emissions our environment cannot afford.

To put it simply, as it currently stands the legislation will allow large companies to pay to pollute. By focusing the legislation on achieving true gross emissions reduction, we can enjoy genuine reductions at the point of production. It is through the lens of true gross emissions reduction that the strength of the safeguard mechanism reforms should be assessed. The Chubb review into the Australian carbon credit unit found it is important to have a policy, but it is critical that it be effective. To be effective, abatement must be real and it has to be known to be real. Following on from this, then, I am moving a second reading amendment calling on the government to commit immediately to implementing and fully funding all 16 of the Chubb review recommendations, which include a range of proposals to improve the operation of the scheme. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government to fully fund and implement all 16 recommendations of the Independent Review of Australian Carbon Credit Units undertaken by Professor Chubb, prior to the commencement of the Act."

This work must be done in time for the safeguard mechanism to commence. While some have criticised the Chubb review for not going far enough, I would argue the recommendations provide us with an important starting point, a floor if you like, for ensuring the quality of Australia's carbon offset regime.

However, whilst uncertainty over the integrity of ACCUs remains, we should look to minimise their use and ensure the hierarchy is clear, with facilities prioritising onsite abatement before externalising their emission reduction obligations. The priority should be on onsite abatement and the direct and real reduction of emissions through technological and efficiency improvements. Once the opportunities for onsite abatement are saturated, then facilities can turn to the safeguard mechanism credits, SMCs, which are intended to be high-integrity, multiyear, science aligned credits in a closed system. Only after these first two options are exhausted should ACCUs then be able to be used. I would also argue that there should ultimately be a cap of, say, five per cent on the number of ACCUs that can be used to ensure compliance with the safeguard mechanism. However, I recognise that this may be something that needs to be phased in over time.

The Australian government has also already announced it will support the decarbonisation of existing industries and the creation of new clean energy industries through the $1.9 billion Powering the Regions Fund. While there are many examples of industries that will undoubtedly need this support and are much wanted in our economy, including things like green cement and green steel, there are also emission intensive trade exposed facilities that will arguably be less desirable in a future economy, including many fossil fuel extraction facilities. The safeguard transformation stream within the Powering the Regions Fund should explicitly state that it is not available to new fossil fuel projects or for the expansion of existing licences, with this legislation instead doing everything it can to ensure these projects all find their way to net zero as soon as possible.

Whilst there has been a lot of discussion around overall emission reduction targets, the pathway to achieving our net-zero goal remains unarticulated. To address this, and in line with previous recommendations by the Climate Change Authority, I propose the government legislates to progressively lower the coverage threshold for the safeguard mechanism from 100,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions down to 25,000 tonnes. This ratcheting down over time would send a very strong investment signal and set a clear trajectory to net zero for industry. Working alongside the reduction in the threshold, the bill should also incentivise broader sections of industry to reduce their direct emissions by allowing them to opt into the scheme and thus opt into generating safeguard mechanism credits. This opt-in stream would have the dual benefit of increasing the number of polluters who will reduce their pollution whilst also increasing the supply of SMCs, so those in the harder to abate sectors will have access to a larger number of high-quality SMCs from within the safeguard mechanism. Then, to enhance anti-avoidance measures outlined by the minister, the bill should be amended to stipulate that facilities which are covered by the mechanism at the commencement of the act will remain covered, even if they reduce their emissions below 100,000 tonnes. Together, these measures will ensure genuine emissions abatement and reduction by the broadest section of large emitters.

Each generation in human history must be held to account for the actions that they take and the legacy they leave. Arguably for those of us born between 1965 and 1980, known as generation X, this decade in this century is that moment of reckoning for us. Those of us who are gen Xers have ultimately witnessed some of the world's greatest advances, including space exploration and the development of the personal computer, and many of this generation have already shaped the world during pivotal years of great change and technological advancement. As a member of that generation, I say to all others who join me as gen Xers: At this time, in this place, we must stand now to ensure the legacy we leave is one we can be proud of. The time for talk is at an end. Let's be the change we wish to see in the world.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Buchholz ): Is the amendment seconded?
Dr Scamps: I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Mr McCORMACK (Riverina) (20:10): Australia is a trading nation. It is a nation that gets things done, a nation that, being an island continent, relies very much on exporting agricultural goods and exporting resources. These exports have made this country what it is today: great. It's absolutely the best nation on earth. What we don't want to do is expose our agricultural industries and our mining resources sector to legislation that is going to hamper their ability to get things done, to produce things.

If you look at Australia's top 20 exports, this is the list for 2019-20, but it wouldn't be much different in 2023. At No. 1 is iron ore and concentrates: $102,864,000,000. They're big figures. That money provides for a lot of public schools and a lot of state public hospitals. It pays for a lot of things. It employs a lot of people. That's just iron ores and concentrates. No. 2, back in 2019-20, was coal, at $54,620,000,000. No. 3 was natural gas. No. 5 was gold—again, mining. No. 7 was beef. No. 8 was aluminium ores and concentrates, including alumina. No. 9 was crude petroleum. No. 10 was copper ores and concentrates. No. 14 was meat, excluding beef—we're talking about sheepmeat. Then we go to wheat at No. 16. No. 17 was aluminium. No. 18 was other ores and concentrates. No. 20 was copper.

I have been a bit selective in reading that list to the parliament. The others that I didn't mention are such things as education related services, travel services, professional services, computer and information services, telecommunications and those sorts of things. While they are big employers, you would almost think they are not that big as emitters, but they would have a carbon footprint—no question. But it's the ones that I numbered in the list that are creating so many jobs and so many opportunities.

I have been in this place long enough—since 2010, as you have too, Deputy Speaker Buchholz—to remember when Labor under the then Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, brought in the carbon tax. I have a lot of respect for the former member for Lalor, but her feet were held to the fire by the Greens, by the Independents Windsor and Oakeshott and by others. She went against what she said she would do. She said 'The government I lead will not bring in a carbon tax' and then they did not long after they were elected in 2010. August was the election. They did indeed introduce a carbon tax. At the time the mantra was about big polluters. Every time they went to that dispatch box over on that side they talked about big polluters. They're smart enough now to change the word 'polluters' to 'emitters', but it makes no difference. What we're talking about here are the likes of the industries, businesses and manufacturers—exporters—that I numbered in that list. Those exporters do not deserve to be demonised, do not deserve to be pilloried, do not deserve to be castigated and do not deserve this legislation. And they certainly don't deserve to be criticised by those opposite.

The debt this country is in—and I know those opposite exaggerate the debt, with backbenchers often getting up and reading their talking points, and good luck to them; we were all backbenchers at one stage—is not anywhere near a trillion dollars. I know that some of those opposite are not good with figures, but we do have a debt. We also hear those opposite ask, 'What did we ever get for the debt?' Well, I'll tell you what we got. We got 50,000 to 60,000 Australian lives saved during COVID. We got hundreds of thousands of jobs saved and hundreds of thousands of occupations saved. Also, many businesses were saved. Businesses which would have otherwise gone to the wall because of the global pandemic now still have their doors open and are still providing goods and services. And some of them, just some of them, are exporting. But they all have carbon footprints, as we all do.

This legislation, the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2022, is a Trojan Horse of a carbon tax—it truly is. If you look at the gross value of those exports that I listed, what you don't want to see is businesses that are providing so much to our gross domestic product being cruelled, being penalised, by the government introducing legislation in this place which it thinks is going to reduce the temperature of the globe. It just doesn't make any sense. I heard the member for North Sydney say we have legacies to leave, and I appreciate that. I do understand that. We have to be good citizens. Moreover, we have to be good global citizens. But, all too often in this country, our schoolchildren are being told, through the sort of curriculum that has unfortunately crept into our schools, that they should be ashamed of our past and that they should probably be ashamed of our future.

We should be very proud of what we as a nation have done. We should be very proud of manufacturing. We should be very proud of the fact that we've got a resources sector which has kept the lights on in this country and which has kept so many jobs. Just take coal, for instance. I'm glad the member for Hunter is here. He's waving. He's happy. Do you know why he's happy? It's because he knows there is a future for the resources sector in the Hunter, and, with his leadership, there will continue to be a resources sector in the Hunter. I'm giving him a plug, but he knows that. Unfortunately there's not too many on that side that do. I know the Minister for Resources quite often gets up and talks about the importance of the resources sector, so much so that I think she should actually be a National, but we'll leave that aside for the moment. The member for Brand certainly is a good egg when it comes to that.

In the adjournment debate we heard from the member for Deakin, who introduced the HomeBuilder scheme during the time of the pandemic. In the construction sector, gross value added was in the order of millions of dollars in 2019-20. It was $142,331 million. That's 7.7 per cent of the Australian economy for gross value added. They're huge figures—massive figures. If you take it as read in 2019-20 certainly one of the things that would be under question, under risk, would be Woodside's North West Shelf project. If you look at that project alone—and I took the opportunity to call it up on the website earlier—the statistics are: 37 years operating, 5,700-plus LNG cargoes since 1989 and $34 billion in investment. In 2021, the North West Shelf contributed $1.9 billion to the Australian economy. These are massive figures. Why should Woodside and other manufacturers and mining companies or, indeed, agriculture, some of those big emitters that those opposite are so fond of demonising, be cruelled? Why should they be hampered? Why should they be restricted? Why should they be limited by ideology? They should not be.

We on this side, as Liberals and Nationals, have always said that we believe in technology, not taxes. But those opposite have never seen a tax that they wouldn't want to impose. They've never seen a tax that they wouldn't want to increase. What they're doing is hurting the job-creating businesses, the job-creating manufacturers, miners and those people who produce the food and fibre, such as those in the member for Mallee's seat and my seat. They are hurting enough, right across the country, with the cost of living.

It's really interesting when you do a bit of reading on this subject to see that the safeguard bill is going to set a price cap on ACCUs that is initially $75—three times the carbon price introduced by the Gillard government. Okay, I accept that. The Minister for Climate Change and Energy already has the power to impose such regulations under the National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Act 2007. We understand that. But there's some really interesting reading material in that the legislation updates the penalty system for facilities not meeting the baseline reduction targets or purchasing sufficient carbon credits. The penalty is set at what per tonne of CO2? Wait for it. This is a figure that I don't think we'll hear from those opposite during this debate. What do you reckon the figure might be? I will tell you: $275. You can't make this stuff up. It's the number that those opposite don't want to mention: $275. That figure is also, coincidentally, the amount of money that those opposite, the Prime Minister in particular, on no less than—how many times was it?
Dr Webster: Ninety-seven.

Mr McCORMACK: Ninety-seven, Member for Mallee—of course it was. That's three less than 100. Ninety-seven times during the election campaign the then opposition leader promised that that's how much they would reduce household bills by. But this sort of legislation has been introduced. No doubt it will go through the House of Representatives. I appreciate the member for Watson extending the parliamentary time so that people can speak on it. He didn't gag debate and I will give him his due. I will give him his credit where it's due. It will go to the other place, to the Senate. I hope there are no deals being done. You wouldn't know with Labor and the Greens. I know that every now and again the Greens feign indignation and hop up and down just to show the media and the public and say, 'No, there's no great relationship between us and Labor,' but we know there is. We know there has been all along. It happened in 2010-11 with the carbon tax. It'll happen again with the climate policies that those opposite are introducing, and it's a shame.

I know that the member for Fairfax is right. He describes the safeguard mechanism as a Trojan Horse, and he is so right. He is so correct. He says Labor's carbon tax won't work. It will weaken the economy and worsen the environment. We do want to see measures that are going to help the environment. We want to see measures being taken to improve our oceans, to improve waste. I think that's one of the biggest things that we need to do not just as a country, a nation, but right around the world. I have been to other places and seen how they regard waste. In fact, there's a complete disregard for plastic waste. The build-up I saw in Nairobi was a rubbish dump you could see from space. I'm not digressing. I think that's one of the greatest challenges for humankind, and we need to address that.

But what we see from those opposite is them always placing taxes above everything else. What we see is them always introducing ideology above practicality, ideology above accountability and ideology above transparency. They say one thing before an election and they do the complete opposite afterwards. That's what really sticks in the craw of ordinary, everyday Australians, who are out there facing cost-of-living pressures—not to mention such things as the Port Kembla Steelworks, the Moomba plant, Pluto LNG, Queensland Curtis LNG plant and Gippsland Basin. They're all what those opposite call 'big emitters', but, as I said earlier, they are job creators. They are opportunity makers. They are factories, plants, industries and people—people!—creating power, creating opportunities, creating wealth and creating exports. They're the ones that we should be absolutely promoting and not cruelling with these stupid policies.

Dr WEBSTER (Mallee) (20:25): That was an excellent speech, I might say, from the member for Riverina. We are at a time of great uncertainty, where costs are rising and business owners are talking to me about their business's viability. Mallee businesses are a large contributor to Australia's food bowl. Against some of the strongest economic headwinds in decades, the policies of the Labor government are ensuring businesses struggle even more. The last thing businesses need right now is additional costs imposed by poor legislation from the federal government, but—lo and behold!—this is exactly what we have in front of us, the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2022.

We have a new carbon tax, and this isn't just the Julia Gillard version. When then Prime Minister Gillard introduced her carbon tax it was priced at $23 a tonne. Anthony Albanese was in her cabinet at the time and must have had grand plans of not only emulating his predecessor but overshadowing her. The current Prime Minister's carbon price is starting at $75 a tonne, and it is rising to $100 a tonne by 2030, as the government looks to cut Australia's emissions by 43 per cent in that time. Is this really in the best interests of Australian businesses, including manufacturing, especially when financial pressure is increasing every day for Australian families and businesses? Why does this government think a carbon tax three times larger than the one the Gillard government introduced is good for Australian businesses and households?

The $75 carbon tax is significantly higher than our trading partners' and basically leaves Australian businesses competitively dead in the water. Labor's carbon price will drive up the cost of living at a time when Australian workers and families can least afford it. Businesses will pass the additional costs straight onto consumers through higher electricity prices—who would have thought!—higher food prices and higher prices for building materials. What choice do they have? The cost of fuel, fertiliser and construction will go up as companies try to buy their way out of emissions reduction obligations that are forced upon them.

Think of the cost to farmers, so central to the livelihoods of many in regional Australia, including in my electorate of Mallee. They are already facing workforce issues, like finding pickers to get fruit off the vine before it falls to the ground. They are already being hampered by supply chain issues, which severely hamper growth and productivity. All the while they are paying increasingly higher energy costs, or, in the case of some, such as Ian Mortlock, a large-scale tomato grower in my electorate, their only option has been to cut back on energy use. This was Ian's only option to keep his operation viable, despite the long-term impact on production.

Businesses having to pass on their costs to consumers is a best-case scenario, because what happens if these higher prices push those same businesses to the wall? People lose their jobs. Families are suddenly deprived of income, at a time when the pressure is mounting just to make ends meet. It is a horrendous thought and not something we need the government actively contributing to through bad policy. As we know full well, it is the regions that will be hit worst by this. After all, that is where we see most of our agricultural and mining businesses located. This government is willing to heedlessly risk livelihoods to meet its emissions targets. It is a recipe for an economic and social disaster.

On our side of the chamber we support achieving net zero emissions by 2050, but this needs to be delivered in a responsible way that balances emissions reduction with economic growth. The way to deliver those emissions reductions is through technology, not taxes. That is why, in 2016, we introduced the safeguard mechanism, ensuring Australia's largest greenhouse gas emitters kept their net emissions below an emissions limit. This mechanism was working just as it was intended; it encouraged businesses and it backed technology.

Labor are now looking to put their own stamp on that mechanism, with potentially disastrous results. Their new signature policy is just a rehash of what Labor governments have been doing right throughout history. They are going back to the Australian Labor Party textbook, penalising businesses that don't meet their agenda and imposing higher taxes on them. We won't sign up to Labor's heavy-taxing, big-government agenda that guarantees everyone pays more under Labor. As the coalition in government has shown and delivered, you can grow the economy and do the right thing on climate change. You don't botch the economy and hurt Australians in the process. That's what this government is doing. The coalition in government supported a carbon-trading system that rewarded businesses that voluntarily reduced their emissions. It brought the emitters along and incentivised them to cut back, while this government has decided to go the sledgehammer approach.

In January, Labor announced changes to the regulations managing the safeguard mechanism. These will reduce the emissions baseline for every facility by 4.9 per cent every year to 2030: a 30 per cent reduction in total. This is a huge drop—the largest government enforced reduction anywhere in the world. To meet the lower baseline, a facility can invest in technology that reduces its carbon emissions, purchase an Australian carbon credit unit for $75 that offsets its emissions or acquire one of the proposed safeguard mechanism credits. A non-compliance penalty will be imposed on facilities that do not meet their baseline emissions and do not purchase sufficient ACCUs or safeguard mechanism credits to offset the shortfall. The proposed penalty will be on a business to pay $275 per tonne of carbon dioxide. Essentially, Labor wants to use a carbon-trading system to force businesses to buy carbon credits. Any way you dress it up, it's a tax. The coalition offered the carrot to businesses; Labor is threatening them with a stick. What's more, unsurprisingly, Labor deliberately tried to hide what they were doing. They refused to release modelling on the impact of their safeguard mechanism, with Minister Bowen claiming it would 'reveal deliberations of cabinet'. Thankfully, the Senate intervened—a win for transparency that this government was attempting to deny. So much for a more transparent government.

We were very clear about our concerns with Labor's proposal before the election. It was another sneaky attempt to impose a carbon tax on the Australian economy. The coalition government mapped out a plan to achieve net zero by 2050 without new taxes. In government we committed $22 billion to bring down the cost of low-emissions technologies such as hydrogen, ultra-low-cost solar, and green steel and aluminium, leveraging up to $132 billion in private sector investment and supporting 160,000 jobs. Once these technologies are cost-competitive with the existing alternative, people will voluntarily make the change. When the government acts sensibly without bowing to a green agenda and balances climate policy with economic growth, that's when we see desirable outcomes. This was the coalition's approach in government, and since 2005 emissions fell by more than 20 per cent while our economy grew by 45 per cent. It is why companies were reducing their emissions already by using carbon capture and renewable energy.

This government seeks to fast-track this, creating chaos in energy markets and increasing the costs of the transition to renewables. This is amid rising electricity prices and reliability risk, as fossil fuels exit the system before reliable replacement renewable generation and backup is actually even in place.

We have seen this government interfere with markets to create a price cap that has just created confusion and dented business and investor confidence in Australia. Now we have the government coming after business again, looking to levy new taxes unless the businesses come on board with their policy. Policy works best when it brings business and people along. It does not work when you hit them with unnecessary taxes at a time when they are most vulnerable.

Ms McKENZIE (Flinders) (20:35): The coalition supports action on climate change. Anyone who suspects otherwise need only flick back through Hansard to December of last year—not to 15 December, when we were brought back at great cost to the Australian taxpayer to consider emergency energy price relief legislation, which, at that time, you could have been forgiven for thinking might actually lower energy bills, but to 1 December, when my colleague the member for Fairfax rose to deliver his response to the Annual climate change statement. In that contribution, the shadow minister for climate change reflected on the coalition government's record:

The former coalition government's record is remarkable. It acted on climate change and managed the decarbonisation of the Australian economy in a way that was balanced and responsible. In 2021-22, as the coalition's time in office was concluding, Australia's annual carbon emissions had reduced by 77 million tonnes from when the coalition was first elected in 2013. That drop of 77 million tonnes meant that, under the coalition, Australia's greenhouse gas emissions fell by over 20 per cent on 2005 levels—an amazing outcome and something that all Australians have every right to feel very proud of.

Based on my short time in this place, the key difference I observe in climate change policy between this side and the other side concerns the importance which we place on sustaining and backing Australia's economic growth and, at the same time, addressing cost-of-living pressures. Our policies have sought to sustain and build the Australian economy and its key industries. The other side's policies have sought to constrain and to punish. As my colleague the member for Fairfax noted in December, reflecting on the coalition's achievements, while emissions reduced to record levels, Australia's GDP increased at an annual rate of 2.5 per cent before the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. This was one of the highest growth rates among OECD countries. We maintained our AAA credit rating and we brought unemployment rates down to their lowest levels in nearly 50 years.

I do not doubt the Albanese government's intent in tackling climate change, but it must be said that this is poor policy. The safeguard mechanism implemented by my predecessor as environment minister in the former coalition government has been working to manage emissions while the economy continued to grow. Labor's proposal is changing the scheme from one whose purpose is to stop emissions by encouraging businesses and backing innovation and technology to a scheme whose purpose is to penalise business and impose taxes. In government, the coalition mapped out a plan to achieve net zero by 2050 without new taxes. Our plan for the safeguard mechanism was to create incentives and support businesses which made the transition to net zero. But this government is determined to see Australia tax its way to net zero—a plan that history shows will fail and may well take parts of the Australian industrial and manufacturing base with it.

Despite the strongest economic headwinds in decades and despite having already whacked businesses with higher energy prices after failing to deliver their election promise of lowering energy prices by $275, Labor now plans to hit the Australian economy with a carbon tax. By pricing emissions at $75 a tonne, Australia will have a price which is three times higher than the one set by the previous Labor government and which is set to rise to $100 by 2030. This tax is significantly higher than the carbon price of eight of our top 10 two-way trading partners, putting our industries at a significant disadvantage. In Labor's rush, they have provided no evidence of the impacts of their policy. In a major reform such as this, people deserve to know the impact, but Labor is refusing to share the detail. What we do know is that many of the industries covered by the safeguard mechanism have strong concerns with many aspects of Labor's policy. Key parts of Australian industry, producers of cement, steel, aluminium, those businesses that are large employers but are in hard-to-abate sectors, have been ignored by Labor.

Two of the businesses targeted by this measure are located in my electorate. They are integral parts of the local economy and they have provided meaningful and rewarding employment to generations of Flinders families. BlueScope produces globally competitive exports, the highly sought after COLORBOND, and Esso supplies energy to the Australian eastern seaboard. Esso's gas fractionation plant at Long Island Point directly employs 80 people and indirectly supports hundreds of other local jobs. On a recent visit there with the Leader of the Opposition, Peter Dutton, we met fourth-generation apprentices on site, participants in Esso's nationally recognised and awarded apprenticeship scheme. BlueScope Western Port employs around 800 people from the region and over 50 years has provided more than 10,000 local jobs. Both are to be found on Labor's hit list for this new carbon tax. In February BlueScope CEO Managing Director Mark Vassella was clear about the potential impact of this measure on future investment in Australian industry. 'There is no value here in seeing carbon exported' Mr Vassella said. 'If steel was to be produced offshore and shipped back to Australia because that capability was not here, that is actually a worse outcome for the planet.'

In this place debate must be had on how we balance our responsibility to reduce emissions while ensuring Australia remains strong, prosperous, globally competitive and independent. In government the coalition achieved this balance. The economy grew up to 23 per cent in our nine years in office while we met and exceeded Australia's Kyoto targets. We signed up to achieving net zero by 2050, and we reduced emissions by over 20 percent on our 2005 base level, putting Australia well on track to beat our Paris treaty commitments. At the same time we lowered energy prices, as the member for Fairfax reminded us all here on 1 December. Over the last term of the coalition government alone, prices dropped for households by eight per cent, for businesses by 10 per cent and for industry by 12 percent. Electricity prices dropped to an eight-year low under the coalition as we reduced pressure on households, lowered costs for businesses and kept Australian industry competitive internationally.

One way we kept prices down was by helping facilitate a rapid growth of the supply of gas. It's why we have been offering the government a gratuitous tip since day one in opposition: supply, supply, supply. As we heard yesterday and again today in this chamber, the Albanese government, in collaboration with the Greens, has put future supply at risk. We are one of the richest countries in the world for natural gas, with now no incentive to produce, explore or extract it.

The future for energy affordability in this country looks bleak. Last week we learnt that Victorian households will cop a 31 per cent increase in the base electricity cost from 1 July. I have honestly lost track of the forecast increases in energy prices modelled over the last six months. Was it 56 per cent for electricity and 44 per cent for gas? All the while the minister for climate change tells us over and over again how lucky we are to have him and how much better things are with him in charge of our energy bills. Well, my constituents aren't feeling it—not one bit. After a decade in which we delicately balanced emissions reduction with economic growth, Labor is now rushing to impose drastic taxes on Australian businesses, for which we will all pay the price.

Mr RAMSEY (Grey—Opposition Whip) (20:43): The rise of atmospheric CO2 levels from 290 parts per million in about 1900 to 414 in 2021 is indisputable. The last time CO2 reached these levels in the atmosphere was about four million years ago. While the effects of these levels on the environment are debatable, most would agree it's causing the atmosphere to heat up. I would be in no position to challenge that consensus. However, what Australia, which contributes about 1.2 per cent of global emissions, should do about it should be a red-hot topic of discussion. The phrase 'red-hot topic of discussion' brings me to the new parliamentary standing orders which the government brought in immediately after coming to government and used its numbers to change. A bill like this tonight is only being debated by one side of politics, and the government has packed up and gone home. I think that is a bit of a disgrace, I must say. I've lost count of the number of times I've raised the completely nonsensical way in which global emissions are accounted for and broadly summed up as design by Europeans for Europeans. It's so important that we work to develop more effective technologies in Australia and that we allow technology to lead us to the desired outcome. However, the Albanese government has made policy decisions which have had ramifications that none of us fully understand at this time. This bill, the safeguard mechanism bill, is just another one of them.

To sum it up, Labor is targeting businesses with more than 100,000 tonnes of emissions per annum and is designating a baseline output for these businesses, determined over a decade ago, maybe, with some unspecified scope for variation of this baseline figure. Having said that, the baseline figure is determined for businesses, and it is incumbent upon them to reduce those emissions by 4.9 per cent per annum. This includes industries such as mining, mineral concentration, refining and fertiliser plants. I've already spoken on a couple of other bills about the threats of these policies to a new urea plant in Western Australia, which would undoubtably reduce global emissions but almost certainly raise Australian emissions. That in itself is one of those paradoxes that I think really needs to be drawn attention to because of some of the unintended consequence of this legislation. It also affects steelmaking and aviation, but not, it seems, generators that contribute to the electricity grid. The government should be able to explain why that is so, but I find it a bit dumbfounding; if we're going to pick on every other industry, why on earth don't we pick on electricity generators? But I suspect it is because they're wearing political heat over a number of other statements they have made, including reductions to power prices of $275 a year, which they are unable to deliver on.

In Grey, this legislation puts BHP Olympic Dam, Liberty Primary Steel in Whyalla and SIMEC in Whyalla firmly in the sights, and if those businesses exceed the 4.9 per cent reduction target then they can compensate by buying carbon offsets, which the government has capped at $75 a unit, bearing in mind that an Australian carbon unit represents one tonne of emissions. It's almost certain the cap will immediately go to the $75 capped price, and it's worth comparing it to Julia Gillard's $23 carbon tax. It would seem that that has now tripled because it is difficult to see this in any other light but a carbon tax.

Last year $17.7 million in Australian carbon credit units were traded in Australia, and each one, as I said, is worth a tonne. We don't know exactly how many we are likely to see in the future and how many the industry is going to need because the government has not given us the Treasury estimates that they have developed this policy on. That is clearly not being transparent at all, and they should share that information with the Australian public. Australian emissions last year were around 480 million tonnes, and we know, as I said, that $17.7 million of Australian carbon credit units were traded. Estimates in the market—and, as I said, we don't have Treasury estimates—are that the market will be very undersupplied, perhaps by 50 per cent, and here's the kicker: if a business can't secure enough carbon credits in what is likely to be a short market, they will be fined not by the equivalent of $75 a tonne but by $275 a tonne—$275. This is a massive fine on these industries, which are our big employers. They are the winners of overseas income, of export income for Australia. In many cases, they are the industries that underwrite our standard of living. 'How big a stick does the government want to hit these industries with?' is the question that I am asking myself.

Imagine you are the industry, or you own or operate it, with an existing investment in legacy equipment. The equipment may not be all that old. It might have a 10-, 20- or 25-year lifespan, but all of a sudden it's not suitable for your industry. You're going to have to buy $75 credits, or maybe even be hit with a $275 fine for not being able to purchase those credits, which you would if only they were available. Imagine the industry that you operate in good faith has no alternative technology available to it. It is a potential economic deathtrap.

Liberty Steel in Whyalla produces about 40 per cent of Australia's steel production. The British owner of Liberty Steel, Sanjeev Gupta, is very enthusiastic about the prospect of green steel, produced from green hydrogen. Of course, it is dependent on green hydrogen that can be supplied at the right price. We know that making steel using hydrogen is technically feasible, but it is not yet known whether it is financially sustainable. I wish Mr Gupta very well in his endeavours to develop green steel in Whyalla; I'd be a very enthusiastic supporter of it, but do I want to cut off my nose to spite my face? No, I don't. If that can't be achieved, I don't want to lose the steel industry in Australia. I'm doubtful whether that industry can support buying carbon credits at $75 a tonne, and I'm very confident indeed that it cannot support paying a $275-a-tonne fine for carbon credits that it could not purchase at $75 a tonne, because they were not available.

We've recently spent a fair bit of time in this place, on one bill or another, talking about sovereign risk for Australia. When Arrium went broke and the business in Whyalla went into the hands of a receiver, I argued in the party room, with the Prime Minister and other ministers, that we could not allow this industry in Whyalla to go under, not just because of the jobs it would destroy in Whyalla, and the hollowing out of that city, but because Australia could not afford to lose that steelmaking plant. Whether or not that steelmaking plant can survive under these new rules is yet to be known, but I think there needs to be a safety net in there. There needs to be a safeguard against the safeguard mechanism, as it were.

Nyrstar in Port Pirie is now owned by Trafigura, and I'm very pleased they do own it. It's a big company that has a very positive attitude to Port Pirie and its smelter down in Hobart. They have built a new, state-of-the-art TSL smelter in Port Pirie and a brand-new sulphuric acid plant. They're there for the long haul. The smelter in Port Pirie is absolutely essential to the operations of the zinc smelter in Hobart. They take the waste from Hobart, reprocess it in Port Pirie and manage to wring enough out of those residues—which were formerly dumped at sea, I might say—to pay for the smelting process. It's a very important cog in the wheel. They have a beautiful new TSL smelter, but they also still use a coke-fired blast furnace. There isn't any technology available to them at the moment to replace that coke fired furnace. They are looking, as the industry worldwide is, at the possibility of using hydrogen in those plants, but at this stage, as far as I know, it's unproven. Like the steel industry, even once they achieve it, whether it is financially sustainable is another question.

There are also concerns about the adaptability and flexibility of the benchmarking. It's unclear—to me, at least—how that works and I suspect it's unclear to most of the industries that are affected by it. However, if the credits and even the fines become a permanent part of those businesses in Whyalla, like Nyrstar and SIMEC Mining, then I doubt their viability.

So what happens? The world needs zinc, lead, gold, silver and other critical minerals. If we drive all that production offshore to a country with no real targets, what have we achieved? We have achieved a worse outcome for the world. It's why we need to be in pace, setting a good clip on this reform in Australia. The problem is, when you cement in targets—as the government has done with the 43 per cent by legislating it rather than just setting a target, as they are doing with this safeguard measure, putting legislated barriers in place—it is very difficult to take your foot off the pedal when it all comes crashing down.

I hold deep reservations about what this will do for a number of the industries that sit within the electorate of Grey. It's not only those that sit within the electorate of Grey. I know other members here tonight have been talking about cement, and it's very right and proper. It is a very energy intensive industry, producing cement to produce concrete. We cannot run a modern industrial society without steel and concrete. They are absolutely essential. They need to be produced somewhere in the world for Australia to use, and I strongly prefer that they be produced in Australia.

I greatly fear that this legislation is a nail in the coffin of those industries, that they will be forced offshore. Those energy intensive industries will find it increasingly difficult to operate in Australia, and we will all be the poorer for it.

Mr T
HOMPSON (Herbert) (20:57): They said they weren't going to give the Australian people more taxes. The government went to the election 10 months ago and told everyone that life would be cheaper under them. They said that they wouldn't raise taxes. And now they want to come after your super. They said the cost of living was going to be cheaper under them. And now they don't want to talk about it. They said that there wouldn't be a carbon tax. And here we are, in the first year of this new Labor government, talking about a new tax, a tax by stealth. Make no mistake: Labor is using the safeguard mechanism to try and smash its way through its legislated emissions targets, and it's going to wreck the economy at the same time.

It isn't just going to hurt small, medium and large businesses, it's going to hurt the family budget. Not only has Labor broken its promise to reduce power bills by $275 for every household in the country, not only has Labor given us an economic environment that's seen inflation soar and interest rates go up every month since the election, but they're going to force businesses to buy carbon credits using a carbon trading system. They're abandoning the good faith system that rewarded businesses that voluntarily reduced their emissions. Instead, they're replacing it with a tax. But what else would we come to expect from this government?

It's got form—for wanting to destroy the economy in an effort to save the planet. We saw it in the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd era, when Julia Gillard introduced her carbon tax. Back then, she priced carbon at $23 a tonne. Now this government has put a starting price at $75 a tonne, rising to $100 a tonne by 2030. This is not the way to go about the task. Taxing businesses when times are already tough is not the way to go, because we know that when businesses are doing it tough they increase their prices. Those cost increases flow onto the consumers through higher electricity prices, higher food prices, higher prices for building materials—the list goes on. That is not what we need when costs are already going up.

As the shadow minister said, there is nothing safe about Labor's safeguard mechanism. It's bad for the economy and it's bad for the environment. Anyone running a car will pay more as the price of oil goes up. Anyone building anything will pay more as the prices of aluminium and steel go up. We'll see farmers pay more for fertiliser because the price of gas to produce it is going up, which means even more-expensive food on our supermarket shelves.

I'll give you an example of how the cost of everything always goes up under Labor. Let me tell you about a constituent in the electorate of Herbert. Peter is an elderly pensioner who lives in Townsville, and he called my office recently. Peter says things are so tight that he has to choose whether to turn on his air-conditioning, run the washing machine or cook his dinner, because he can't afford to do all those things at once. His power bills keep going up and up. And now, with this tax, Peter can expect to be paying even more for the goods and services he needs for his everyday life. That's just one example among so many different examples that come through my office and many others' offices. When I go around talking to people in the electorate of Herbert and ask them what's important to them, there are two top issues. The first in Townsville is always crime. Townsville has an out-of-control crime problem, which contributes to the increased cost of insurance and all the other things that leads to, not to mention the emotional cost. But the second issue they raise is almost always the cost of living—higher power bills, higher fuel bills, higher grocery bills. That is all this is going to do.

But there's another side to Peter's situation that I think is very interesting, and that is that he has solar panels on his roof. He has an app on his phone that tells him exactly how many kilowatts of power his solar panels are generating. That's why he can't make sure he's using the most power when he's getting it free from the sun. And what do you know? He's not producing any emissions while that electricity is being generated. Peter has done what this government should be doing: he has put technology to good use. He's reached into his pocket and made an investment, and it's has paid off. He hasn't been able to sort the issues that arise when the sun doesn't shine, at night, when he has to pay for power from the grid. But he's used technology to his advantage to help with the issue.

That is the difference between the coalition and Labor. We know we can reduce emissions with technology, not taxes. That is what we did in government, and we were able to meet and beat our Kyoto targets and were well on track to beat our Paris treaty commitments. At the same time, we were improving the Australian economy. Our economy grew by up to 23 per cent over the nine years we were in government. That's because we invested in technology, not taxes.

Let me give an example of that in the electorate of Herbert. I've spoken about it in this place before, but for the benefit of this new parliament I will outline it again. When we were in government, we funded $15.5 million for the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and the Australian Renewable Energy Agency for five trucks in Townsville which will be powered by green hydrogen that's being produced in Townsville. The proponent is Ark Energy, a sister company of Sun Metals, which runs a zinc refinery which has been operating in Townsville for decades. The investment will enable two things: firstly, the purchase of five of the largest hydrogen fuel cell heavy haul trucks in the world; and secondly, a one-megawatt electrolyser to produce hydrogen, powered by Sun Metals' massive on-site solar farm.

Ark Energy's SunHQ Hydrogen Hub is expected to produce up to 158 tonnes of hydrogen a year. The five 140-tonne trucks will transport zinc from Townsville port to the Sun Metals refinery, where the hydrogen will be produced. The trucks will be able to refuel and return zinc back to the port in a 30-kilometre round trip. Currently these operations are powered by diesel. Under this project they will avoid 1,300 tonnes of CO2 emissions each year. Ark Energy plans to upscale its operations within years to produce enough hydrogen to supply the domestic market, which is expected to see very strong growth. After that, they will focus on the export market, with plans to send hydrogen offshore to customers throughout Asia. Everything that is learnt about hydrogen throughout this project will also help others who are keen to improve their sustainability as well. This is technology, not taxes. This is what we need to be doing more of—helping businesses like Ark Energy invest in these new ventures.

We need to be incentivising businesses to reduce their emissions, not punishing them. We should be keeping this voluntary, not making it compulsory. That's why, in government, we also committed to investing $70 million for a hydrogen hub in Townsville. This money will help companies develop and accelerate the growth of a local clean hydrogen industry. It's another example of direct action and investment in technology that doesn't take from businesses' bottom lines or hit the hip pocket of everyday people already doing it tough. We supported net zero by 2050. We committed to $22 billion to bring down the cost of low-emissions technology like hydrogen, ultra-low-cost solar, green steel and aluminium, leveraging up to $132 billion in private sector investment and supporting 160,000 jobs. The reason is that once these technologies get to a point where they are cheaper than what is already available, people will voluntarily make the change to technologies that produce fewer emissions.

The fact with this legislation is we don't know how much it's going to cost the people of Australia. We don't know because the government won't tell us. In fact, the government hasn't even asked Treasury or its department to do the modelling. It's just another example of the sneakiness of this government when it comes to trying on new taxes. Not to mention the fact that when Australian businesses shut down because of this tax, consumers will look elsewhere. If they can't get a product in Australia because a producer has to shut down because of this tax, the consumers will look to overseas. They will look to places like India and China, some of the biggest emitters. That's not going to do anything to help with climate change. It's only going to shift the problem somewhere else and shift the responsibility along with it.

We on this side of the House firmly believe that technology, not taxes, is the answer. We heard in question time today that you will have cheaper power bills because of this, that this bill will help with the cost-of-living pressures. These are simply not true. We heard a question from the crossbench around methane, and the minister couldn't rule out that as another punishment or tax on our farmers. This is a tax on the barbecue. This is a barbecue tax. Under the cover of this bill, this will see higher taxes, higher punishment for Australian businesses and for Australian consumers. It will see businesses—small, medium and large—close, which will hurt consumers and will see people taking advantage of going offshore. This does not help our economy. This will hurt our economy. That's why I'm speaking against this bill today.

Mr VAN MANEN (Forde—Chief Opposition Whip) (21:10): It's always a pleasure to follow the member for Herbert and his considered contribution to any debate in this House. As we once again talk about a Labor government introducing the latest version of a carbon tax, all I can see is the economic damage that will be done in addition to the economic damages already being incurred by so many Australian households and businesses due to this government's reckless emission reduction policies.

Now, I don't for one minute disagree with the notion that we have a changing climate and that we need to be responsible citizens in how we look after our environment for future generations, but taxes are never those solutions. Tax is never the solution to this problem. But it seems that, once again, we're talking about a bill that is going to introduce a tax into our economy at the very time that we're already battling rising and high inflation rates.

Energy is in everything we consume, and this bill, the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2022, is adding to the cost of that energy, is adding to the cost of our transport systems. All of that ultimately feeds into inflation. And ultimately, if we maintain a higher inflation rate, all of that feeds into higher interest rates. People with mortgages and people who are renting will pay the price doubly through higher rents or higher mortgage payments and through higher cost-of-living payments for things such as groceries. I do not see why a policy like this is of any economic value to the Australian people at this point in time—or any other time, for that matter.

The coalition put its best foot forward and committed to net zero by 2050, but that isn't what we are debating here. Both sides of this House agree on a target of net zero by 2050. What this debate is about is delivering this target of net zero by 2050 in a responsible way that balances our need to reduce emissions but also ensures that we maintain a viable level of economic growth not just for current generations of Australians but for generations to come. And that is why the coalition, when we were in government, took the path of delivering emission reductions through technology, not taxes. Enhancing technological innovation is a critical way to accelerate our ambitions of reducing emissions over the longer term. This was the approach that the previous coalition government outlined as the best way forward.

What we're seeing instead is a government addicted to new and higher taxes—in this case, a reintroduction of the carbon tax. The last thing business in Australia needs at this time is higher costs. You will well remember, Deputy Speaker Claydon, the impact of the carbon tax last time, as you were here, elected with me, in the class of 2010. We are very clear about our concerns about Labor's proposal.
Ms Mascarenhas interjecting—
Mr VAN MANEN: I appreciate the comment from the member for Swan, who is new to this House, but it may behove her well to look at the history of this and to look at some of the detail.

To rub salt into the wounds of this proposed carbon tax, it's being introduced amidst a full-blown cost-of-living crisis. Interest rates have increased a record 10 consecutive times. Power prices have gone through the roof for most households and businesses. And in this environment, this Labor government has decided to tax Australian industry even further.

What I find really interesting is that last sitting week we were debating a piece of legislation in this House called the National Reconstruction Fund Corporation Bill, where the government wishes to see manufacturing grow and develop in this country. One of the things that manufacturing needs is low-cost, reliable energy. I can tell you, Madam Deputy Speaker Claydon, that when I talk to businesses in my electorate that is the last thing they are seeing, and this is only going to make the situation worse. On one hand you've got the government saying, 'We want to see manufacturing grow and prosper in this country', and on the other hand you're seeing the government put a noose around their necks by having higher and more punitive business costs.
Ms Mascarenhas interjecting—
Mr VAN MANEN: Member for Swan, you've had your chance. If you want to debate, take the opportunity to speak on this if you haven't already. I don't need your interjections in this debate.

Labor needs to focus on the impact of their power price rises on Australian businesses doing it tough now. As we've seen, this government, in introducing this new tax, isn't even prepared to release the modelling. This is a government that, in the lead-up to the election, was all about transparency, yet it's failed to release the modelling to show the impact of this policy on the Australian economy. What is this government hiding? Why aren't they prepared to release the modelling? That is why the coalition will continue to ask for this modelling to be released—because the government has refused to do so.

Let's take this opportunity to reflect on the coalition's record, as mapped out in the plan to achieve net zero by 2050—as I said earlier, with technology, not new taxes. We committed $22 billion over 10 years to develop low-emissions technology, leveraging up to $132 billion in private sector investment, supporting 160,000 jobs. I look at companies like EcoJoule Technology, in my electorate; I first met them several years ago when they were at Meadowbrook, and they've now moved to Loganholme. It is a great network technology that helps improve the stability of networks where you've got high levels of solar and intermittent energy being fed in. In addition, they have a battery system that helps modulate that as well when there are power outages. They're the sorts of companies we should be supporting and encouraging to continue to develop their projects. The former coalition government, with its plans, was also focusing on technology such as clean hydrogen and long-duration energy storage, so that they became cost-competitive with higher-emitting alternatives and that they could be voluntarily taken up by consumers. That is the right way to do it. As I have said in this place previously, nobody needed government subsidies to buy a Model T Ford. Nobody needed government subsidies to develop or buy an Apple computer, or any other computer for that matter; the market took care of those things. What government intervention and subsidies do is actually distort markets, and very often governments fail to actually get it right.

Under the coalition government—those opposite might not like this particular figure—we saw emissions fall by more than 20 per cent since 2005, while the economy grew by 45 per cent. This was done in a way that allowed Australians to cut emissions while providing them viable low-emission alternatives, further proof that you can reduce emissions and grow the economy through a technology-not-taxes approach. The coalition government, when we were in government, beat our Kyoto-era targets by 459 million tonnes without imposing a job-destroying carbon tax. We set out a credible plan to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 while preserving existing industries and regions. A number of other contributors on this side—the member for Hinkler in his contribution and the member for Capricornia in her contribution—outlined very well the impact of these proposals on those regions in regional Queensland to generate enormous wealth for our country and pay enormous royalties to the Queensland state government that allowed the Queensland state government to provide health, hospital and education services to our community. Those opposite and those on the crossbench have never in any way acknowledged that and have certainly never in any way come up with an alternative for how those services are going to continue to be provided to the Australian community if those industries that currently pay those royalties are closed down. In government, the coalition also supported a carbon trading system that rewarded businesses that voluntarily reduced their emissions, but this is not what the government is proposing. They want to use a carbon trading system to force business to buy carbon credits. The reality of that is that it is a tax, no matter which way you cut it.

As I said earlier, by taxing Australians this government's approach will see the cost of everyday items like petrol, groceries and building materials increase. In the member for Kennedy's contribution, he raised, I think, a very salient question and that is also question those opposite and many on the crossbench have failed to address—that is, the issue of wholesale land clearing for big wind farms and for commercial-scale solar farms. Now, any of my rural colleagues in here will know the damage that that causes, yet this is the hypocrisy of those opposite and those on the crossbench. If a farmer goes to clear that land, what are the chances? Nil to zero and probably big fines to go with it. So our farmers in this country, who are some of the best agriculturalists in this world and who produce actual wealth and food for this nation, not only food for this nation but food for many other nations overseas, are prevented from growing their businesses and providing more and better quality food to Australians and those overseas that we export to yet, at the same time, commercial-scale solar farms and windmills are allowed to clear land wholesale with very few if any questions asked. There is no discussion even had about what happens when those solar farms and those windmills get to the end of their useful life. How are they recycled or reprocessed? How are those solar panels recycled or reprocessed for future use so they don't go into landfill?

There are myriad unanswered questions in this headlong rush to use technologies that provide intermittent, unreliable power. The very manufacturing industries that this government is seeking to support, such as steel, aluminium and other major manufacturing businesses that employ hundreds of thousands of Australians, will struggle to keep their doors open with the cost of electricity and the restrictions that are placed on them. So the very thing that this government wishes to achieve will be completely and utterly undermined with policies such as this. Just as we as a coalition called into question the veracity of the National Reconstruction Fund and how that would and wouldn't work, we are equally right to call into question this safeguard mechanism and the damage it will do to the Australian economy in a whole myriad of ways: higher cost of living, potential job losses and, worst of all, the transfer of our national wealth overseas because business will go overseas because it no longer can afford to keep its doors open.

Mr COULTON (Parkes—Chief Nationals Whip) (21:25): I've got a real feeling of deja vu coming over me here tonight.
